prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the 12CO, CS and 13CO lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.39 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be 1 kpc (2 arcsec) for this source.

Past CO(3-2) spectrum is not readily available for this galaxy, therefore, we scale the CO(3-2) intensity of IRAS 17207 using the ratio of the FIR luminosity, assuming a linear correlation between FIR luminosity and CO(3-2) luminosity (Iono et al. 2009). The ratio of FIR luminosities is 0.74, therefore, we estimate the peak of the CO(3-2) to be 35 mJy with the ALMA beam (the peak of IRAS 17207 is 47mJy; see TJ for IRAS 17207). We aim to achieve a uniform mass sensitivity for all of the sources observed in CO(3-2) in this program, with a molecular gas mass sensitivity of ~10^7 Msun (~0.5% of the molecular gas mass of the MW galaxy) which is equivalent to RMS = 2mJy. Assuming a beam filling factor of 10%, which is typically what we find from past measurements, the S/N achieved with an RMS = 2 mJy is S/N = 180 at the peak. The 13CO line is typically 5% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with a S/N ~ 10. Similarly, the CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with S/N ~ 5 - 10. The 10 km/s resolution should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the HCN, HCO+ and CS lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.39 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be less than 0.5 kpc (1 arcsec) .

From our past ALMA observations toward a similar IR bright galaxy VV114, we find that the peak of the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) are typically 1/10 of the peak of CO(3-2), yielding 35 mJy with the ALMA beam. We request RMS = 1.8 mJy in order to detect the HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)lines at S/N = 20 in 10 km/s resolution. The true signal is likely higher since HCN/HCO+ is likely more compact than CO. The 10 km/s resolution should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected. The CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with S/N ~ 5 - 10.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the 12CO, CS and 13CO lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.28 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be 1 kpc (1.4 arcsec) for this source.

We use the SMA map of IRASF17207-0014 (Wilson et al. 2008) to calculate the desired sensitivity. The peak of the CO(3-2) line is 600 mJy with a ~1 arcsec beam. Scaling this to the 0.28 arcsec ALMA beam gives a 47 mJy peak. Assuming a beam filling factor of 10%, which is typically what we find from past measurements, the peak is estimated to be 470 mJy. We aim to achieve a uniform mass sensitivity for all of the sources observed in CO(3-2) in this program, with a molecular gas mass sensitivity of ~10^7 Msun (~0.5% of the molecular gas mass of the MW galaxy) which is equivalent to RMS = 2mJy. The S/N achieved will be S/N > 220. The 13CO line is typically 5% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with a S/N > 10. Similarly, the CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with S/N ~ 10. The 10 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected.
The 345GHz continuum is 48 mJy with the 1 arcsec beam. Scaling this to the 0.28 arcsec ALMA beam gives 4 mJy. Even with a filling factor of unity, the expected S/N > 6. The true signal is likely much higher since the filling factor is less than unity.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the HCN, HCO+ and CS lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.39 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be less than 0.5 kpc (1 arcsec) .

From our past ALMA observations toward a similar IR bright galaxy VV114, we find that the peak of the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) are typically 1/10 of the peak of CO(3-2), yielding 47 mJy with the ALMA beam. We request RMS = 2mJy in order to detect the HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)lines at S/N > 20 in 10 km/s resolution. The true signal is likely higher since HCN/HCO+ is likely more compact than CO. The 10 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected. The CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with S/N ~ 10.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the 12CO, CS and 13CO lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.30 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be 1 kpc (1.5 arcsec) for this source.
We are aware that this source transits just around sunset when the requested configuration occurs, and may require favorable observing conditions.

According to Papadopoulos et al. (2010), the peak intensity of IRAS05189 is x3 lower than IRASF17207. Therefore, we estimate the peak intensity to be 16 mJy with the ALMA beam (see TJ for IRAS 17207). Assuming a beam filling factor of 10%, which is typically what we find from past measurements, the peak is estimated to be 160 mJy. We aim to achieve a uniform mass sensitivity for all of the sources observed in CO(3-2) in this program, with a molecular gas mass sensitivity of ~10^7 Msun (~0.5% of the molecular gas mass of the MW galaxy) which is equivalent to RMS = 2mJy. The S/N achieved will be S/N ~ 80. The 13CO line is typically 5% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with a S/N ~ 4 . Similarly, the CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 3 - 4. The 10 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the HCN, HCO+ and CS lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.39 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be less than 0.5 kpc (1 arcsec) .
We are aware that this source transits just around sunset when the requested configuration occurs, and may require favorable observing conditions.

From our past ALMA observations toward a similar IR bright galaxy VV114, we find that the peak of the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) are typically 1/10 of the peak of CO(3-2), yielding 16 mJy with the ALMA beam. We request RMS = 0.8 mJy in order to detect the HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)lines at S/N = 20 in 10 km/s resolution. The true signal is likely higher since HCN/HCO+ is likely more compact than CO. The 10 km/s resolution should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected. The CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 3 - 4.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the 12CO, CS and 13CO lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.29 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be 1 kpc (1.5 arcsec) for this source.

Past CO(3-2) spectrum does not exist for this galaxy, therefore, we scale the CO(3-2) intensity of IRAS 17207 using the ratio of the FIR luminosity, assuming a linear correlation between FIR luminosity and CO(3-2) luminosity (Iono et al. 2009). The ratio of FIR luminosity is 0.41, therefore, we estimate the peak of the CO(3-2) to be 19 mJy with the ALMA beam (see TJ for IRAS 17207). Assuming a beam filling factor of 10%, which is typically what we find from past measurements, the peak is estimated to be 190 mJy. We aim to achieve a uniform mass sensitivity for all of the sources observed in CO(3-2) in this program, with a molecular gas mass sensitivity of ~10^7 Msun (~0.5% of the molecular gas mass of the MW galaxy) which is equivalent to RMS = 2mJy. The S/N achieved will be S/N ~ 100. The 13CO line is typically 5% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with a S/N ~ 5 . Similarly, the CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 3 - 4. The 10 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected.

We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.39 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be less than 0.5 kpc (1 arcsec) .

From our past ALMA observations toward a similar IR bright galaxy VV114, we find that the peak of the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) are typically 1/10 of the peak of CO(3-2), yielding 19 mJy with the ALMA beam. We request RMS = 1 mJy in order to detect the HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)lines at S/N ~ 20 in 30 km/s resolution for this galaxy. The true signal is likely higher since HCN/HCO+ is likely more compact than CO. The 30 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected. The CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 3 - 4.

Past CO(3-2) spectrum does not exist for this galaxy, therefore, we scale the CO(3-2) intensity of IRAS 17207 using the ratio of the FIR luminosity, assuming a linear correlation between FIR luminosity and CO(3-2) luminosity (Iono et al. 2009). The ratio of FIR luminosity is 0.41, therefore, we estimate the peak of the CO(3-2) to be 19 mJy with the ALMA beam (see TJ for IRAS 17207). Assuming a beam filling factor of 10%, which is typically what we find from past measurements, the peak is estimated to be 190 mJy. We aim to achieve a uniform mass sensitivity for all of the sources observed in CO(3-2) in this program, with a molecular gas mass sensitivity of ~10^7 Msun (~0.5% of the molecular gas mass of the MW galaxy) which is equivalent to RMS = 2mJy. The S/N achieved will be S/N ~ 100. The 13CO line is typically 5% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with a S/N ~ 5 . Similarly, the CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 3 - 4. The 10 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected.

We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.39 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be less than 0.5 kpc (1 arcsec) .

From our past ALMA observations toward a similar IR bright galaxy VV114, we find that the peak of the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) are typically 1/10 of the peak of CO(3-2), yielding 19 mJy with the ALMA beam. We request RMS = 1 mJy in order to detect the HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)lines at S/N ~ 20 in 30 km/s resolution for this galaxy. The true signal is likely higher since HCN/HCO+ is likely more compact than CO. The 30 km/s resolution should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected. The CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 3 - 4.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the 12CO, CS and 13CO lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.17 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be 1 kpc (0.9 arcsec) for this source.

According to Papadopoulos et al. (2010), the peak intensity of IRAS12112 (both North and South) is x2 lower than IRASF17207. Therefore, we estimate the peak intensity to be 32 mJy with the ALMA beam (see TJ for IRAS 17207). Assuming a beam filling factor of 10%, which is typically what we find from past measurements, the peak is estimated to be 320 mJy. We aim to achieve a uniform mass sensitivity for all of the sources observed in CO(3-2) in this program, with a molecular gas mass sensitivity of ~10^7 Msun (~0.5% of the molecular gas mass of the MW galaxy) which is equivalent to RMS = 2mJy. The S/N achieved will be S/N > 150. The 13CO line is typically 5% of the 12CO line, and will be detected with a S/N ~ 7 - 8 . Similarly, the CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 5. The 10 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected.

We use the FDM mode of the correlator with 1.875 GHz bandwidth and 3.5 km/s resolution (8 channel binning) to reduce the data rate for the HCN, HCO+ and CS lines. We will average three channels to obtain our spectral resolution of 10km/s, and this is much smaller than the predicted linewidth of the source. We will use the TDM mode of the correlator for the continuum band which will be observed in baseband 4.

The angular resolution should be sufficiently high in order to detect gas clumps at 200 pc scale. We have therefore chosen the angular resolution of 0.39 (200pc) for this source. We estimate the largest angular scale to be less than 0.5 kpc (1 arcsec).

From our past ALMA observations toward a similar IR bright galaxy VV114, we find that the peak of the HCN(4-3) and HCO+(4-3) are typically 1/10 of the peak of CO(3-2), yielding 32 mJy with the ALMA beam. We request RMS = 1.6 mJy in order to detect the HCN(4-3)/HCO+(4-3)lines at S/N = 20 in 10 km/s resolution for this galaxy. The true signal is likely higher since HCN/HCO+ is likely more compact than CO. The 10 km/s resolution should should be enough to investigate the detailed kinematics in this galaxy, and we will adopt a wider resolution in case the signal is weaker than we have expected. The CS line is typically a few% of the 12CO line, and will be marginally detected with S/N ~ 5.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Hierarchical galaxy formation scenario predicts that galaxy-galaxy interaction and merger are the fundamental process that govern the evolution of galaxies in the universe, changing the galaxy morphology and triggering intense starbursts and/or AGN activity. Recent high resolution simulations have shown that tidal interaction is responsible for forming massive clumps of dense gas surrounded by diffuse gas clouds and triggering star formation across the galaxy disks. An observational test of gas response requires mapping both the diffuse and dense gas tracers in merging U/LIRGs at high spatial resolution. Here we propose a systematic CO(3-2), HCN(4-3), HCO+(4-3) survey of 6 of the brightest merging ULIRGs in the local universe at 0.3 arcsec (200 pc) resolution of ALMA Band 7. The primary aim of this study is to map the distribution and kinematics of warm/dense molecular gas and the dense gas mass fraction and interpret their relation to star formation and AGN activities in the context of the merger-induced response of the ISM in the progenitor disks.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00099.S: Highest Priority 2011.0.00467.S: Highest Priority 2012.1.00280.S: Filler 2013.1.00080.S: Highest Priority
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
